title-group.article-title: The antitumor effects of tetrodotoxin and/or doxorubicin on Ehrlich ascites carcinoma-bearing female mice

article-meta.aff: Department of Zoology, Faculty of Women’s for Arts, Science and Education, Ain Shams University, Egypt

author-notes.corresp: Elham H A Ali, Department of Zoology, Faculty of Women’s for Arts, Science and Education, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt. Email: elhamhassan2006@yahoo.com

abstract.p: The study aimed to investigate the antitumor effect of tetrodotoxin (TTX) and/or doxorubicin (DOX) on Ehrlich ascites carcinoma (EAC)-bearing mice through the investigated biochemical parameters. TTX and/or DOX with or without N-acetylcystiene were administrated after 10 days into EAC-female mice for a period of 2 weeks in six equal doses. Treatment with TTX or DOX caused a significant decrease in the mean tumor weight and an increase in the cumulative mean survival time when compared with EAC group. All the treatments reduced the elevated liver tumor markers and increased liver antioxidant enzymes under investigation in comparison with EAC. Hepatic cells, suffered severely from degeneration and karriolysis in EAC group, revealed some improvement as appearance of healthy hepatocytes by TTX treatment. The present results suggested that TTX had a more powerful inhibitor effect on EAC growth than DOX and TTX plus DOX treatments reflected by antitumor biochemical and histological studies.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cancer continues to represent the largest cause of mortality and the major public health problem in most parts of the world and claims over 6 million lives every year (Jemal et al., 2008). The deadliest part of the cancer process, metastasis, appears to rely on the help from macrophages, potent immune system cells, that usually defend vigorously against disease. Metastatic tumor growth is inhibited if these unusual macrophages are killed. In addition, metastatic disease is the major cause of cancer mortality (Pollard, 2009).

Doxorubicin HCl (DOX) is a cytotoxic anthracycline antibiotic isolated from Streptomyces peucetius var. caesius (Arcamone et al., 1969a, 1969b). It possesses a broad spectrum of antitumor activity, exhibits a wide activity against leukemias and breast, lung, thyroid and ovarian carcinomas as well as against Hodgkin’s and non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas (Longhu et al., 2006). But its clinical use is limited by its adverse side effects: irreversible degenerative cardiomyopathy and congestive heart failure (Aleisa et al., 2007; Lee et al., 2009).

Tetrodotoxin (TTX) is a naturally occurring potent toxin and a highly selective sodium channel blocker (Fouda, 2005). The toxin name is ascribed to the puffer fish (Tetraodontidae), the most commonly available source of TTX (Hwang and Noguchi, 2007). N-acetylcysteine (NAC), an aminothiol, is a sulphydryl group donor and precursor of glutathione (GSH) (Zandwijk, 2004). It is considered as one of the most promising cancer chemopreventive agents (Shi et al., 2009).

It is well recognized that apoptosis is a mode of cell death used by multicellular organisms to eradicate cells in diverse physiological and pathological settings (Huo et al., 2004). One of the hallmarks of apoptosis is the cleavage of chromosomal DNA into nucleosomal units. The degradation of DNA in the nuclei of apoptotic cells is accomplished in a number of ways following the activation of caspases. DNA topoisomerase II is a nuclear enzyme essential for DNA replication and repair. Caspases can inactivate this enzyme leading to DNA damage (Herrera-Mendez et al., 2006). Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) is an extraordinarily pleiotropic cytokine with a central role in immune homeostasis, inflammation, and host defense (Warren et al., 2009). Dependent on the cellular context, it can induce such diverse effects as apoptosis, necrosis, angiogenesis, immune cell activation, differentiation, and cell migration. These processes are of great relevance in tumor immune surveillance and also play crucial roles in tumor development and tumor progression (Wajant, 2009).

So, the present work was designed to investigate the antitumor activity of TTX and/or DOX with antioxidants NAC on Ehrlich ascites carcinoma (EAC) mice and to test whether the treatment with both natural toxin TTX and synthetic agent DOX together has an effect on the antitumor property of each.

sec.title: Influence of sex on the growth of the Ehrlich ascites tumor
sec.p: The present study was conducted to investigate the influence of sex on the growth of the Ehrlich ascites tumor in the peritoneal cavity and between thighs for the formation of liquid and solid tumors in 30 male and 30 female mice weighing 22–25 g. The results revealed that significantly less growth occurred in male mice than in female mice inoculated with tumor cells. The solid tumor did not grow up in male mice and formed scars and infiltration of pus cells. This may be due to the Ehrlich cells that were discovered in the female breast (breast cancer), and hence, the female hormones may affected its growth. This is consistent with Vincent and Nicholls (1967). They found that EAC cells show greater initial growth and higher total cell count in female mice than male mice. So, the present study used the female mice.

sec.title: Tumor cell line
sec.p: The initial inoculation of EAC cells was kindly provided by the National Cancer Institute (Cairo University, Egypt). EAC cells were thereafter propagating in our laboratory by weekly intraperitoneal (IP) injection of 2.5 × 106 cells per mouse, which was carried out according to the method recommended by the Egyptian National Cancer Institute, Cairo University. Cells were counted before injection using the bright line hemocytometer and dilutions were made by physiological saline, and the desired number of cells was injected in a volume of 0.5 ml per mouse.

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: Adult female Swiss albino mice weighing 22–25 g were obtained from the animal house of Egyptian National Cancer Institute, Cairo University. The local committee approved the design of the experiments, and the protocol conforms to the guidelines of the National Institutes of Health. The animals were maintained on a standard pellet diet and tap water ad libitum.

sec.title: Doxorubicin
sec.p: DOX was manufactured by Pharmacia Italia SPA.

sec.title: Tetrodotoxin
sec.p: TTX was obtained from the skin of the puffer fish or fugu (Arothron diadematus) according to the method of Kawabata (1978). The skins of two masked puffer fish (A. diadematus) were prepared using acidified methanol extract solution. The extract was then boiled for 10 min, cooled, centrifuged at 1000 r/min for 3–5 min and the supernatant containing the TTX was stored at −4°c until used.

sec.title: Assessment of toxicity (mouse units)
sec.p: The toxicity of TTX extracted from the fish skin was determined in mouse units. The mouse unit is defined as the amount of toxin required to kill a mouse weighing 20 g within 30 min (Fouda, 2005; Kawabata, 1978).

sec.title: N-acetyl cysteine
sec.p: It is obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Company (USA).

The tested compounds were administered at a dosage of 15 mg/kg body weight (bwt) of DOX (Timao and Singal, 2000); 1/20 lethal dose (LD) of TTX (Fouda, 2005) and 50 mg/kg bwt of NAC (Kalaiselvi et al., 2005).

sec.title: Animals were assigned into eight groups
sec.p: The first group received IP injection of physiological saline and served as a control group. The groups 2 to 8 were injected subcutaneously with 2.5 × 106 EAC/ml in the back between the thighs of each animal to form a solid tumor (Fahim et al., 1997). Groups 3–8 received IP injection of DOX (G3; 15 mg/kg); TTX (G4; 1/20 LD); TTX + DOX (G5; injected TTX half hour before DOX administration); NAC + DOX (G6; 50 mg/kg NAC 1 h before DOX administration); NAC + TTX (G7; TTX (1/20 LD) and NAC 1 h before TTX administration) and NAC + TTX + DOX (G8; injected with doses of NAC 1 h before TTX and TTX half hour before DOX), respectively. Six injections of equal dosage were given on a daily basis for a period of 2 weeks. All the groups were killed on the 24th day of experiment for sampling and examination of biochemical and histological parameters (10 days after inoculating the EAC cells (when the tumor becomes papale) + 14 days of treatment).

sec.title: Antitumor studies
sec.p: The antitumor activities of DOX, TTX and/or NAC were assessed on 350 mice used to determine the mortality rate and to calculate the mean tumor weight (MTW) until the end of study. The latter were classified into seven equal-sized groups (groups 2–8), each group containing 50 mice. Ten days after inoculating the EAC cells (when the tumor becomes papale), the animals in group 2 received no treatment and served as the tumor control group. The animals in groups 3–8 were injected as mentioned before. Then, these groups were left untreated until the end of the experiment. The weight of the solid tumor was determined by killing three animals every week and by taking the MTW. The cumulative mean survival time, the increase in life span (ILS, %) and the tumor growth inhibition ratio (T/C, %) were recorded as given by Fahim et al. (2003). Mean survival time is the days at which the animals were alive. ILS, % = mean survival time of test/mean survival time of control × 100. Tumor inhibition ratio (T/C, %) = MTW of control − MTW of test/MTW of control × 100.

sec.title: Biochemical measurement
sec.p: At the end of the 24 days of experimental period, six mice were fasted overnight, anesthetized under diethyl ether (Sigma Co., USA) and the blood was collected by cardiac puncture into dry clean heparinized tubes. The blood tubes were left for 30 min and then centrifuged at 3000 r/min for 30 min. After centrifugation, the plasma was separated at once, divided into aliquots and stored at −70°C until used in the biochemical analysis. Plasma glucose concentration was determined according to the method of Young (2001) using kits purchased from SPINREACT Company (Egypt). Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PHD) was measured according to the method of Kornberg et al. (1955) using kits purchased from Bio-Diagnostic Company.

Liver was excised immediately from the animals (mice) after dissection and carefully washed with cold saline, dried and weighed. Fresh liver sample, usually 0.5 g, was homogenized in 5 ml of 0.9% NaCl saline and used for determination of the following: liver γ-glutamyltransferase (GGT) was determined by the method of Szasz and Persjn (1974) using a commercial kit purchased from Egyptian company for Biotechnology (Egypt). Hepatic TNF-α was determined using a corresponding enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay kit purchased from Bender Med-Systems Company (Europe). Activity of Caspase-3 was determined by the method of Kamada et al. (1998) using the Caspase-3 Assay Kit, colorimetry (Product Code CASP-3-C) from Sigma-Aldrich Company. Total protein in liver tissue was determined by the method of Young (2001). Malondialdehyde (MDA), as one of the main end products of lipid peroxidation, is currently estimated by the thiobarbituric acid test according to the method of Ohkawa et al. (1979) using commercial kit purchased from Bio-Diagnostic Company (Egypt). Liver GSH content was determined according to the method of Beutler et al. (1963). Activity of glutathione S-transferase (GST) was determined by the method of Habig et al. (1974). Activity of liver glutathione peroxidase (GPX) was measured by the decrease in reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate according to the method of Gross et al. (1967). Activity of superoxide dismutase (SOD) was carried out by monitoring the auto-oxidation of pyrogallol, according to the method of Minami and Yoshikawa (1979). All chemicals were purchased from Sigma Co. (USA).

sec.title: Histological examination
sec.p: For histopathological study, during dissection, parts from the livers of the previous animals from each group were separated and stored in 10% buffered formalin. They were later sectioned (5S thick) using a microtome, dehydrated in graded alcohol, embedded in paraffin section and stained with hematoxylin and eosin (Drury and Wallington, 1980). Then they were viewed using a Lecia-DM2500 (Germany) microscope.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Reported values represent means ± standard error. Statistical analysis was evaluated by one-way analysis of variance. Once a significant F test was obtained, least significant difference (LSD) comparisons were performed to assess the significance of differences among various treatment groups. Statistical Processor System Support “SPSS” for Windows software, release 12.0 (SPSS, Chicago, Illinois, USA), was used.

sec.title: Antitumor studies
sec.p: Table 1 reveals that the treatment of tumor-bearing animals with TTX (G4) and NAC + TTX (G7) induced an increase in the life span (ILS, %), which amounted to 153.33 and 160, respectively, compared with tumor-bearing controls (G2). The DOX-treated (G3) and NAC + DOX-treated (G6) groups showed an increase in the life span (ILS, %), which amounted to 140 in both the groups, while the life span is recorded as 58.88 and 80 in TTX + DOX-treated (G5) and TTX + NAC + DOX-treated (G8) groups, respectively, when compared with tumor-bearing controls. On day 60, at the time when all tumor-bearing control animals were dead, the MTW was recorded as 9.50 ± 0.17. The mean weight decreased significantly in G4- and G7-treated groups to reach 4.90 ± 0.14 and 4.90 ± 0.06, respectively. While in G3- and G6-treated groups, MTW recording decreased significantly 3.66 ± 0.14 and 5.21 ± 0.04, respectively, in relation with tumor-bearing control. On the other hand, on day 48, at the time when all animals of G8 were dead, the MTW recorded 2.61 ± 0.06, while it reached to 0.67 ± 0.03 in G5 at 30 days with the elevation of the T/C (%).

caption.p: Antitumor activities of TTX, DOX and/or NAC on solid Ehrlich ascites carcinoma compared with tumor-bearing controls.

fn.p: PTI: post-tumor inoculation; M: mortality; MTW: mean tumor weight (g); MST (days): mean survival time; ILS: increase of life span; T/C: tumor inhibition ratio; DOX: doxorubicin; T: tumor group; TTX: tetrodotoxin; NAC: N-acetylcysteine; SE: standard error.
aSignificant change from tumor group (T).
bSignificant change from (T + DOX) group.
cSignificant change from (T + TTX) group.
dSignificant change from (T + TTX + DOX) group.
eSignificant change from (T + NAC + DOX) group.
fSignificant change from (T + NAC + TTX) group at p ≤ 0.05.

sec.title: Biochemical studies
sec.p: The data presented in Table 2 reveals a significant increase (p < 0.05) in liver caspase-3, TNF-α, GGT and plasma G6PHD in tumor-bearing mice when compared with the normal control mice. Treatment with TTX, DOX, NAC + DOX, NAC + TTX and NAC + TTX + DOX markedly reduced these levels when compared with tumor-bearing mice. All the groups exhibited a significant decrease in the level of plasma glucose in comparison with the control mice (p < 0.05). Table 3 shows that the activities of liver SOD, GST and GSH decreased significantly, while the activity of GPX and MDA content significantly increased in the tumor-bearing mice in comparison with the control mice. Treatment with TTX, DOX, TTX + DOX, NAC + DOX, NAC + TTX and NAC + TTX + DOX significantly increased the level of activity of liver SOD, GST and GSH when compared with the tumor group. Also, all the treated groups exhibited a marked increase in liver GPX and MDA content (p < 0.05) when compared with tumor mice.

caption.p: Liver Caspase-3 (micromoles para-nitroaniline (PNA) per minute per milligram protein), liver TNF-α (ng/g wet tissue), liver GGT (U/g), plasma glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (U/ml) and plasma glucose (mg/dl) of control, tumor-bearing mice and treated tumor-bearing mice.a

fn.p: TNF-α: tumor necrosis factor-α; GGT: γ-glutamyltransferase; DOX: doxorubicin; T: tumor group; TTX: tetrodotoxin.
aThe results are presented as mean of six mice ± standard error.
bSignificant change from control group.
cSignificant change from tumor group.
dSignificant change from DOX group.
eSignificant change from TTX group.
fSignificant change from TTX and DOX group.
gSignificant change from NAC and DOX group.
hSignificant change from NAC and TTX group at p < 0.05.

caption.p: Levels of liver SOD (µg/gm), GPX (mg/g), GST (conjugate 1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene (CDNB) per minute per milligram tissue; µm/mg/min), GSH (mg/g tissue) and MDA (nmol/gm) of control, tumor-bearing mice and treated tumor-bearing mice.a

fn.p: SOD: superoxide dismutase; GPX: glutathione peroxidase; GST: glutathione S-transferase; GSH: glutathione; MDA: malondialdehyde; DOX: doxorubicin; T: tumor group; TTX: tetrodotoxin.
aThe results are presented as mean of six mice ± standard error.
bSignificant change from control group.
cSignificant change from tumor group.
dSignificant change from DOX group.
eSignificant change from TTX group.
fSignificant change from TTX and DOX group.
gSignificant change from NAC and DOX group.
hSignificant change from NAC and TTX group at p < 0.05.

sec.title: Histological changes in liver tissue
sec.p: Examination of liver sections of mice injected with EAC displayed severe changes in liver cells marked by wide dilatation in portal veins surrounded by leukocytic infiltration and presence of necrotic foci in the tissue surrounded concentric inflammatory infiltration (Figure 1(b)). Inspection of liver sections injected with DOX revealed some changes in the tissue demonstrated by wide dilatation in central vein with congestion of erythrocytes and leukocytes. Thickening in the central vein wall was observed due to the accumulation of fibers around the wall lining, which displayed complete separation in some areas and destruction in others (Figure 1(c) and (d)).

caption.p: Light micrograph of the liver sections. (a) Control liver with central vein (CV) and surrounding hepatocytes. (b) Liver sections of the group treated with Ehrlich tumor 24 days after Ehrlich cells injection with vacuolar degeneration (VD), inflammatory leukocytic infiltration (arrows) near a dilated portal vein (PV). (c) and (d) Liver sections of the group treated with DOX after 24 days of Ehrlich injection appearing with wide dilatation in central vein (CV) with congestion (C), thickening in its wall due to accumulation of fibers (arrows). Necrotic lesions (NL) in the tissue and aggregations of inflammatory cells (arrows) were displayed. (e) Liver sections of the group treated with TTX after 24 days of Ehrlich injection showing dilatation in portal vein (PV) surrounded by aggregations of inflammatory cells (In) besides necrotic lesions. (f) Liver sections of the group treated with TTX appearing with healthy hepatocytes around normal central vein (CV). (g) Liver sections of the group treated with TTX + DOX displayed wide dilatation in portal veins (PV) with accumulation of fibers (F) in its walls and also around bile duct. Large necrotic areas (NA) were found. (h) Liver sections of the group treated with NAC + DOX after 24 days of Ehrlich injection with large area of inflammatory infiltrative cells (In) besides the necrotic foci (Nf). Deposited layers of fibers (F) appeared in between infiltration cells. (i) Liver sections of the group treated with NAC + TTX with dilatation in central vein, necrotic lesions (arrows), leukocytic infiltration (In) and depositions of fibers (F). (j) Liver sections of the group treated with NAC + TTX + DOX showed deformation of the liver architecture, deposition of great amount of fibers (F) in necrotic areas and numerous aggregations of leukocytic inflammatory cells (In). Magnifications, ×200 ((a), (d), (e), (f), (i), and (j)) and ×100 ((b), (c) and (g)). DOX: doxorubicin; TTX: tetrodotoxin; NAC: N-acetylcysteine.

sec.p: Examination of liver sections in mice injected with TTX showed necrotic foci in the tissue and dilatation of blood sinusoids. While other sections revealed an improvement in the liver tissue marked by the appearance of healthy hepatocytes arranged in some extent similar to that of the normal architecture (Figure 1(e) and (f)). The wall of portal veins was thickened due to the accumulation of concentric layers of fibers around the walls and also around the bile ducts. Moreover, great destruction in some areas of the wall surrounded by necrotic areas was noticed after treatment with TTX + DOX (Figure 1(g)).

Liver sections of mice injected with NAC + DOX revealed leukocytic inflammatory cells with necrotic foci and fibrous layers were deposited in the tissue (Figure 1(h)). Accumulation of fibers were deposited in necrotic lesions surrounded by inflammatory cells, in addition to dilated central vein with congestion noticed in the liver of mice treated with NAC + TTX (Figure 1(i)). Macroscopically, livers from the mice treated with NAC + TTX + DOX displayed dangerous effects on the liver marked by the accumulation of deposited fiber layers in necrotic lesions and scattering of great amounts of inflammatory cells as shown in Figure 1(j).

sec.title: Antitumor studies
sec.p: In the present study, treatment of tumor-bearing mice with DOX or TTX alone and with doses of DOX + TTX and/or NAC exerted a marked effect in the retardation of tumor growth. A more pronounced effect was observed in the single treatment with TTX, which is represented by higher increases in the life span of animals and the tumor inhibition ratio (37.2%). These observations are consistent with the previous findings by Fouda (2005) and supported by Roger et al. (2004) and Fernandes et al. (2006), as they reported that TTX has a great ability to bind to the transmembrane glycoprotein forming Na+ channel that resulted in blocking it, hence reducing the proliferation, migration and invasive properties of the cell line by about 30%. The action mechanism of TTX on EAC is probably not different from that of other cells in the nervous system. It plays an important role in binding to p-glycoprotein of the Na+ channels, blocking it and preventing Na+ influx into the cells. This action, in turn, prevents the carcinoma cells from getting sufficient Na+ ions for the requirements of various intracellular functions, and above all to maintain the normal charge distribution across the cell membrane, a process necessary to maintain cellular integrity. As a consequence, the proliferation and invasiveness of such cells are suppressed (Bragadeeswaran et al., 2010).

The results of the present study also demonstrated that the treatment with DOX alone caused significant decrease in MTW and increases the mean survival time of tumor-bearing mice. This decrease in MTW may attribute to the action of DOX, which binds to DNA by intercalation and inhibits replication and transcription. So, it inhibited the proliferation of EAC cells as well as DNA synthesis and mitosis (Gumushan and Musa, 2008; Ivic et al., 2005; Shi et al., 2009). Moreover, Minotti et al. (2004) found that the mechanisms of action of DOX are multiple. First of all, it forms a covalent complex with DNA topoisomerase, thus preventing the activation of this enzyme. Second, DOX intercalates in the DNA bone and leads to single- or double-strand breaks. Third, hepatic metabolism of the drug leads to the production of oxygen reactive species, which, in turn, damages DNA and causes cell death.

The present investigation clearly demonstrated that the application of NAC with TTX or DOX to tumor-bearing mice had no effect on the action of both drugs. De Flora and Albini (1997) found that the intravenous treatment of female mice with NAC and DOX, mixed together with the same injection, produced marked inhibition in the weight of primary tumors or in the mean number of lung metastases and improved the survival time of the mice.

In the current study, the increase in the tumor inhibition ratio accompanied by decline in ILS (%) treatment with doses of TTX + DOX and NAC + TTX + DOX may be due to short life span and damage to the liver and heart and also due to double oxidative stress of the two molecules. Such finding is in agreement with Deepa and Varalakshmi (2003), who reported that DOX administration produces free radicals that cause destruction to cardiac membrane by increasing the lipid peroxidation, and also DOX causes death in animals by damaging several key organs, such as heart, liver and kidney (Kramer et al., 2006). Also, Callaway et al. (2001) explained the chemical structure of TTX molecule that contains positions with negative charge that can act as free radicals, and these free radicals induce increase in reactive oxygen species (ROS). However, the present findings are in line with the main concept of cancer research that evaluation of any tested substance depends on the extension of the survival time of cancer patients and that an increase in the life span of ≥125% in drug-treated tumor-bearing mice is considered indicative of presumptive drug activity (Abd El-Dayem et al., 2010; Fahim et al., 2003).

sec.title: Biochemical studies
sec.p: In the present investigation, tumor-bearing mice showed higher increases in the activity of caspase-3, indicating increase in apoptosis. O’Donovan et al. (2003) and De Heer et al. (2007) found that the activity of caspase-3 was significantly higher in carcinomas tissue than in the corresponding normal tissue. Also, the activity of caspase-3 is increased in tumor cells due to the inactivation of p53 (tumor suppressor protein), which is responsible for protecting cells from tumorigenic alterations (Ramnath et al., 2009). The elevation in the TNF-α level in tumor-bearing mice may be attributed to the increase in the production of ROS by macrophages, which stimulate lipid peroxidation and thought to have an important pathogenic role in the liver damage (Hoek and Pastorino, 2002). In the present study, tumor-bearing mice showed a significant elevation in liver GGT, which may indicate the development of primary or secondary carcinoma. Strasak et al. (2008) reported that GGT expression may be an early marker of neoplastic transformation.

The present data revealed a significant reduction in liver caspase-3-induced apoptosis as well as in the levels of GGT and TNF-α in TTX-treated groups. The obtained data are in parallel with the result of Banasiak et al. (2004) who reported that reducing Na+ entry with the voltage-sensitive sodium channels blocker, that is, TTX, attenuated apoptotic cell death via a reduction in caspase-3 activation. Several explanations were found for decreased caspase-3 and induction of apoptosis by TTX to block the Na+ K+-pump (Chueh et al., 2001). ROS production might contribute to the pump failure correlating with a more severe block of Na+ K+-pump leading to apoptotic insults (Wang et al., 2003). In support to these results, Roselli et al. (2006) mentioned that Na+ influx through voltage-gated sodium channel (VGSC) is required for lymphocyte activation and proliferation, since these responses are blocked by Na+-free medium or by VGSC blockers. The present results revealed that the dramatic reduction in DOX-induced activation of caspase-3 as well as the levels of liver GGT and TNF-α in DOX-treated groups may be due to early activation of p53 by DOX in both normal and tumor cell lines and prevented apoptosis in tumor cell lines. Such findings are in agreement with the results of Tsang et al. (2005). Also, Chua et al. (2006) reported that the activation of p53, which in turn promotes apoptosis of tumor cells, is considered to be a key mechanism of action of antitumor drugs, including DOX. Wilson et al. (2004) attributed that decrease in the short-term expression of proinflammatory cytokines such as TNF-α can be beneficial to the heart.

Furthermore, tumor-bearing mice showed a significant decrease in the level of plasma glucose and significant increase in the activity of G6PHD. The decreased level of glucose could be explained by the high rate of glycolysis of tumors, regardless of whether their oxygen supply is adequate or low. This characteristic of tumor cells leads to a stringent dependence on extracellular glucose for maintaining intracellular levels of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and may also be important in the acidification of the extracellular environment (Fahim et al., 2003). The increased G6PHD could be explained by Frederiks et al. (2007) who found that G6PHD expression is enhanced in tumor-bearing mice by oxidative stress induced by agents that either increase the intracellular concentration of O2 or decrease the GSH pool.

Moreover, the deprivation of the plasma glucose in TTX-treated group could be ascribed primarily to Na+ load and oxidative stress. The basis for this is an increased utilization of ATP by the Na+ pump activated by a Na+ entry coupled with the inability of mitochondria to respond adequately with increasing ATP production because of the limitation in respiratory capacity under oxidative stress (Wang et al., 2003). In agreement with these observations, in the present work, it was found that a significant depletion of G6PHD in TTX-treated group could be due to severe oxidative stress, which has caused the inactivation of G6PHD that correlated with oxidative damage. Therefore, nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH), the major cofactor produced by G6PHD/oxidative limb of the pentose phosphate cycle, is vital to cellular defense against oxidative stress (Iraimoudi et al., 2002). However, in the present study, treatment with DOX induced a significant decrease in the levels of glucose and G6PHD in the plasma of treated mice. The decrease in glucose level agreed with the findings of Hrelia et al. (2002). In cardiomyocytes, DOX treatment caused a maximal increase in glucose uptake at 1 h, demonstrating that glucose transport may represent an early target for DOX. Otherwise, the decrease in the levels of G6PHD in the plasma of mice treated with DOX may be due to the oxidation of proteins (riboses) that are critical for maintaining proper cellular functions, such as DNA repair. In addition, G6PHD is necessary for adequate NADPH production, which is utilized in the reduction of nucleotide diphosphates to deoxyribonucleic acids and is therefore necessary for synthesis of DNA as mentioned by Ayene et al. (2002).

The present results recorded an increase in the hepatic MDA of tumor-bearing mice, which may indicate the development of primary and secondary carcinoma (Whitby et al., 1993). Excessive production of free radicals results in the oxidative stress leading to the damage of macromolecules such as lipids and can induce lipid peroxidation in vivo (Abd El-Dayem et al., 2010; Gupta et al., 2004). The reduction in the levels of GSH in tumor-bearing mice may be attributed to increased rate of transformation of GSH to oxidized GSH as a result of GSH consumption to get rid of hydrogen peroxide. The other possible reason could be the inhibition of GSH synthesis or a lack of amino acids used in synthesizing GSH (Pompella et al., 2007). The present study recorded significant elevations in the hepatic GPX as well as depletion in the levels of SOD and GST of tumor-bearing mice when compared with normal mice. Such finding is in agreement with Navarro et al. (1999) and Fahim et al. (2003). They reported that the increase in the GPX and decrease in SOD and GST is due to the oxidative stress on the host in response to the continual generation of free radicals by the increasing tumor load.

In the present investigation, treatment with TTX induced a significant increase in liver GSH and MDA contents. These results could be explained from the chemical structure of TTX molecule, which contain positions with negative charge that can act as free radicals. These free radicals may induce increase in ROS (Callaway et al., 2001). In this line, Fukuda et al. (2005) found that the oxidative stress reduces Na channel availability, which could explain the significant increase in the level of MDA in TTX-treated mice when compared with the control. In the present investigation, TTX treatment caused a significant reduction in GPX and GST and an increase in the activities of SOD. A possible explanation for TTX protection and decreasing ROS was supported by Garciarena et al. (2008), who reported that the existence of a direct mitochondrial action of Na+/H+ exchanger 1 (NHE-1) inhibitors in preventing ROS release. They concluded that a mitochondrial action of NHE-1 inhibitors should lead to revisit or reinterpret previous landmark observations about their beneficial effect in several cardiac diseases.

The present findings indicated that the level of MDA and GSH was significantly increased in comparison with the carcinogenic group in the DOX-treated group. This increase may be due to the metabolism of DOX, which lead to the release of iron ions. These ions, therefore, become more reactive in liver (Kalender et al., 2005; Shi et al., 2009). Free iron ions released from iron-containing proteins participate in the generation of hydroxyl radicals (Catala, 2009). Salvemini et al. (1999) reported that GSH synthesis was shown to be induced in cells exposed to oxidative stress as an adaptive process. On the other hand, in the present results, the possible reasons for the lowered activities of GPX and SOD of the liver tissue treated with DOX might be due to the inhibition of enzyme protein synthesis as well as the inhibition of enzymes by DOX, metabolites or some lipid peroxidation products (Mukherjee et al., 2003). Furthermore, Abd El-Dayem et al. (2010) stated that DOX affects liver cells and thus produces free oxygen radicals and causes hepatotoxicity. This explanation is consistent with the present work, which showed that DOX has dangerous histological effects on the liver reflected by the appearance of dilatation with congestion and thickening in the central vein wall due to the accumulation of fibers, and leukocytic infiltration was abundant in addition to necrotic lesions that were scattered in the tissue. The increased activity of liver GST in DOX-treated group was explained by Goto et al. (2001) who attributed to the findings of increased expression of GST, an isozyme of GST, that has been found in the nucleus of cancer cells resistant to DOX and protected DNA from damage by anticancer drugs. In the same trend, Doi et al. (2004) reported that increased GST-π expression in normal and tumor cells may protect them against drug-induced oxidative stress and, thus, apoptosis.

Both TTX and DOX drugs have oxidative stress mechanism as discussed above (Kalender et al., 2005; Shi et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2003). Another explanation for the mechanism of the two drugs was suggested by Tandon et al. (2005) who showed that oxidative stress is not always detrimental, as it can sometimes be beneficial in cancer. Hence, oxidative stress can act as a double-way sword in malignant states. Their theory was in same trend with the present results, where treatment with each of the two drugs TTX or DOX alone induced a significant improvement in the cancer stage and decrease in ROS, but TTX is more effective. However, treatment with TTX + DOX induced a high damage to the mice and less effect than each drug alone through all investigated biochemical parameters.

sec.title: Histological studies
sec.p: Histopathological alterations and congestion in the liver tissue of mice treated with TTX were observed by Yamaguchi (1996). Administration of TTX offers some protection to the liver, which is revealed by decreasing the levels of liver marker enzymes (GGT and TNF-α) and increasing the level of nonprotein thiols (GSH and GST). This may be due to the higher efficacy of TTX in scavenging various free radicals as supported by Fouda (2005). The present results coincide with the results of Abd El-Wahab and Fouda (2009), as they found that no detectable structural changes in the liver tissue of mice injected with 1/20 LD of TTX. Also, Lu and Cederbaum (2006) recorded that no necrosis was observed in liver tissue from mice treated with cisplatin. The present work demonstrated that DOX has dangerous effects on the liver. Most of the previous mentioned alterations in the liver tissue, as a consequence of DOX application, showed similarity and confirmed those reported in rats (El-sayyad et al., 2009; Fang et al., 2004). It is also evident from the histopathological changes of the present results, where acute to chronic infiltration of phagocytic cells around the portal tract of the liver and in the tissue was found, indicating inflammation in this organ due to TTX- and DOX-induced oxidative burden. Also, oxidative stress-induced lipid peroxidation has been implicated in malignant transformation (Gonzalez, 1999). In addition, enhanced lipid peroxidation are concomitant with the decrease in reduced GPX, which is indicative of oxidative stress that provides evidence of the relationship between lipid peroxidation, tissue damage and inflammation (Geetha et al., 2001).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study has demonstrated that TTX had a more powerful inhibitory effect on EAC growth and fewer side effects than DOX reflected through increasing life span of mice and decreasing MTW. This effect may be due to the increased hepatic antioxidant activities; therefore, TTX may be useful as a new natural therapeutic for cancer. Also, the present data do not encourage the treatment of TTX with DOX together in the same time to get a strong and synergetic effect to each other.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: The authors thank Dr Karima Meaawad, Department of Zoology, Faculty of Women’s for Arts, Science and Education, Ain Shams University, for helping in histology in this work.
